articles.title: Warming climate a factor in Boston's growing rat population, new study indicates
articles.author: Darin Zullo
articles.summary: A new study found that the warming climate may be partially responsible for Boston's growing rat population. The study used data from 16 cities around the world to examine rat population trends. Of these 16 cities, 11 saw significant increases in rat populations. Washington, D.C., San Francisco, and Toronto were among the cities with the largest increase in rat sightings.

articles.title: New Zealand experienced the coldest January since 2017, according to NIWA
articles.summary: Last month was the coldest January New Zealand's experienced since 2017. The nationwide average temperature was 16.4°C. It was a dry month for many regions. Auckland was the warmest, Hamilton the driest, Tauranga the sunniest, Dunedin the coolest, and Christchurch both the wettest and least sunny.

articles.title: Top climate scientist declares 2C climate goal 'dead'
articles.author: AFP
articles.summary: Hansen and co-authors argue that Earth's climate is more sensitive to rising greenhouse gas emissions than previously thought. They argue that the amount of greenhouse gases pumped into the atmosphere by burning fossil fuels means increased warming is now guaranteed. The world's nations agreed during the landmark Paris climate accord of 2015 to try to hold end-of-century warming to 1.5C above pre-industrial levels.

articles.title: Top climate scientist declares 2C climate goal 'dead'
articles.author: AFP
articles.summary: Holding long-term global warming to two degrees Celsius is now impossible, according to a new analysis published by leading scientists. Earth's climate is more sensitive to rising greenhouse gas emissions than previously thought, says James Hansen.      Â

articles.title: Top climate scientist declares 2C climate goal 'dead'
articles.author: ANDY BUCHANAN
articles.summary: Holding long-term global warming to two degrees Celsius is now impossible, according to a new analysis published by leading scientists. The fallback target of the Paris climate accord is 2 degrees C.C.  as a result of the current global warming trend.

articles.title: ‘Lifesaving' climate programs are on hold as Musk targets USAID
articles.author: The Washington Post
articles.summary: Trump is moving to shutter the main vehicle of U.S. international humanitarian aid efforts. Environmental and climate programs have also been impacted by the move.       i.e. the UNICEF, the UNFPA, the World Food Programme and others.

articles.title: Trump picks former chief entangled in 'Sharpiegate' to lead NOAA
articles.author: SETH BORENSTEIN
articles.summary: Trump nominates Neil Jacobs to lead the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. Jacobs was acting NOAA chief in 2019 when Trump altered an expected hurricane impact map in what became known as the 'Sharpiegate' scandal. Jacobs will be confirmed by the Senate on Tuesday.

articles.title: Maryland's 2025 Midwinter Waterfowl Survey Shows Higher Bird Counts
articles.summary: Aerial survey teams of pilots and biologists from the Maryland Department of Natural Resources and U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service have completed their annual population estimates of ducks, geese, and swans along the state's Chesapeake Bay, tidal Potomac River and Atlantic coast shorelines. This year, the teams counted about 705,300 waterfowl, which was higher than both the 593,200 birds observed in 2024 and the most recent 5-year average of 624,300 birds. The 2025 midwinter survey was conducted during the first two weeks of January. The survey was not conducted in 2021 due to the COVID pandemic.

articles.title: Greenland's ice sheet is fracturing faster than ever; what it means for rising sea levels
articles.author: TOI Trending Desk
articles.summary: Greenland ice sheet is cracking faster than before due to climate change. Crevasses are getting bigger and deeper where ice is flowing more quickly. Greenland contains enough ice to add seven meters (23 feet) of sea level rise to the world's oceans if the entire ice sheet were to melt.

articles.title: NASA Radar Shows a Surge in Landslide Activity in California
articles.summary: There is a growing risk of landslides on the Palos Verdes Peninsula in Los Angeles County, California. The area has an ancient landslide complex that has been active for the past six decades. The acceleration of the landslides can be attributed to record-breaking rainfall in California in 2023 and heavy precipitation in early 2024. The city of Rancho Palo Verdes is fighting back against landslides through the Portuguese Bend Landslide Remediation Project.

articles.title: Logging stopped in Tasmanian Devil habitat
articles.author: The Echo
articles.summary: Fi Gipters, Jenny Weber and Colette Harmsen returned to protest and halt logging of ancient forests near Lake St Clair in Waykaywirinu/Central Highlands yesterday. They are concerned about the impact of deforestation on climate change and extinction of Tasmanian Devils.

articles.title: American bald eagles are having a moment, ecologically and culturally
articles.summary: The federal government took eagles off the endangered species list in the early 2000's. More states have followed suit. The eagles are doing well in the environment and culturally, as well as in their natural environment.      Â

articles.title: EarthTalk: Changing cows' diets could help with methane problems
articles.author: Pexels.Com Via Earthtalk
articles.summary: Cattle cause a large share of global methane emissions that fuel global warming. What can be done besides reducing or eliminating meat consumption? EarthTalk would like to hear from you about it.   .   "EarthTalk" is on air at 9 p.m. ET.

articles.title: Green, resilient infrastructure is the only way forward
articles.author: Joe Speicher
articles.summary: Australia and Pacific partners are set to be among the most affected by climate change. In Australia, we're seeing changes to our rainfall patterns and an increase in fire danger and extreme events. Sea levels are rising and the ocean is becoming more acidic in the Pacific Ocean.

articles.title: Trump taps 'Sharpiegate' meteorologist to lead top science agency
articles.author: AFP
articles.summary: Neil Jacobs has been nominated to head the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. He was involved in the infamous "Sharpiegate" scandal during Donald Trump's first term. He caved to political pressure to mislead the public about a hurricane forecast. His new nomination has already drawn sharp criticism.

articles.title: Researchers blame CA wildfires on climate change, pedal ‘alarmist' non-peer reviewed studies: Experts
articles.summary: The World Weather Attribution (WWA) group has published a study claiming that the LA wildfires were caused by climate change. The group is backed by billionaire Jeff Bezos and the progressive George Soros Foundation and receives funds from the Grantham Institute and the European Climate Foundation. Some environmental critics are pushing back on the group's rise to notoriety in the media and classified the group as 'alarmist' and 'propaganda'

articles.title: Grim prediction following rare sighting of 'vagrant' crocodile on southern Queensland beach
articles.author: Brianne Tolj
articles.summary: A two-metre crocodile was spotted on a beach near popular camping spot K'gari in south-east Queensland on Monday. It is 380km from its usual habitat at Boyne River near Gladstone. The crocodile is likely the same one that was seen near Bundaberg, 300km north, last month. Experts predict crocodiles will migrate further south due to climate change.

articles.title: Counties with the coldest winters in Montana
articles.summary: The data represents the average temperatures from December 2023 to February 2024. The historic average is the average for these months from 1901 to 2000. The data is based on the historical average for the months from 1951 to 2000, not on the data from 2023-2024.

articles.title: Deaths of 30,000 fish off WA coast made more likely by climate change, research finds
articles.author: Petra Stock
articles.summary: Marine heatwaves off the WA coast are 20 times more likely to occur because of climate change, according to the non-profit group Climate Central. The most affected period in November is 100 times more common. The heatwave off WA coast has killed 30,000 fish and damaged seagrass meadows.

articles.title: Trump Rehires Neil Jacobs, Former NOAA Chief Involved in ‘Sharpiegate'
articles.author: Christopher Flavelle
articles.summary: President Trump nominated Neil Jacobs to lead the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. Dr. Jacobs was the acting head of NOAA in the first Trump administration when Mr. Trump claimed in the summer of 2019 that Hurricane Dorian would hit Alabama. After a NOAA meteorologist in Alabama posted on social media that Dorian wouldn't affect Alabama, the president's staff ordered NOAA leaders to say the meteorologist had been wrong, or risk being fired.

articles.title: Trump nominates 'Sharpiegate' scientist to lead US weather agency NOAA
articles.author: Mike Bedigan
articles.summary: Donald Trump nominated Neil Jacobs to lead the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. He was involved in 'Sharpiegate' when he altered a map to show Hurricane Dorian would hit Alabama. He wrote a statement in support of the president's false projection and criticized NOAA's meteorologists for contradicting Trump's claim. Jacobs and then-NOAA communications director Julie Kay Roberts violated the agency's scientific integrity policy with the statement.

articles.title: Dry Conditions Prompt Fire Restrictions In Otago's Alpine Area
articles.author: New Zealand Government
articles.summary: Otago's alpine area has been placed into a restricted fire season from 8am, Wednesday 5 February until further notice. Anyone who wants to light an outdoor fire will need a permit authorised by Fire and Emergency New Zealand. The current warm, dry weather is forecast to continue over the next few weeks, raising the fire risk in the alpine environment.

articles.title: Does globalisation have a future?
articles.summary: Last year was Earth's hottest since recordkeeping began. Donald Trump is trying to reduce the economic aspect of globalisation. Populists blame trade and immigrants for most of their countries' problems. Globalisation can be reversed, but it's unlikely to be as it was in the 19th century.

articles.title: STATEMENT: Forestry, Wildlife & Parks Division, on World Wetlands Day 2025
articles.author: Malaika
articles.summary: Every year on February 2nd, the Secretariat of the Ramsar Convention on Wetlands, raises awareness about the importance of wetlands and calls on governments, organizations and individuals to protect our planet's wetlands. The theme of World Wetlands Day 2025 is 'Protecting Wetlands for Our Common Future'. The Forestry, Wildlife and Parks Division of the Ministry of Environment, Rural Modernization, Kalinago Upliftment, and Constituency Empowerment conducted a school visit on Monday February 3rd, 2025 to the Woodfordhill Primary School to sensitize the students about wetlands in Dominica.

articles.title: Growing climate crisis means urgent action needed
articles.summary: The planet's average temperature has increased by 1.1 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels. Extreme weather events have increased by 50 percent. The Paris Agreement aims to limit warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius, but current trends hint that we are headed for a 2.7 degrees Celsius rise by 2100. Everyone has a role to play in addressing the climate crisis.

articles.title: Climate change is overhauling marine nutrient cycles, UC Irvine scientists say (University of California, Irvine)
articles.author: Public Technologies
articles.summary: Computer models reveal how human-driven climate change will dramatically overhaul critical nutrient cycles in the ocean in 2025. When the ocean warms it gets more stratified, which can drain certain parts of the surface ocean of nutrients, as shown in the model studies.

articles.title: America's 'Serengeti' at risk: Population-driven sprawl threatens the Greater Yellowstone Ecosystem
articles.author: The Overpopulation Project
articles.summary: Population growth and development threaten America's protected areas, according to a recent report. The Everglades, Arctic plains and the Great Lakes are some of the most vulnerable areas.    i.e. the Arctic plains, Great Lakes, Everglade and Great Lakes.

articles.title: NiMet Predicts Early Rainfall in 2025, Warns of Flash Floods in Coastal Regions
articles.author: Agnes Ekebuike
articles.summary: The Nigerian Meteorological Agency has released its 2025 seasonal climate prediction. It predicts an early onset of rainfall across the country and warns of potential flash floods in coastal areas. Naija247news reports that the forecast has raised concerns among farmers, urban planners, and residents in flood-prone areas.

articles.title: Lack of support for Scottish produce is pathetic and short-sighted
articles.author: Readers
articles.summary: In 1968 a great storm caused havoc in Scotland, particularly in Glasgow. More than 20 people died, trees fell and roofs were torn from tenements. In the latest Storm Eowyn, many trees were damaged but only one life was lost. With climate change, fires in the USA, Canada and Australia, floods in Europe and drought in Africa, some counties will soon no longer be able to sustain life. How much of the food we eat in Scotland is produced here? Supermarkets gather supplies in the south but do not source much from here. English, Irish, Danish and even New Zealand butter regularly is available. Bread, the world's most basic food, is largely imported.

articles.title: FEMA hosts agriculture industry recovery center
articles.author: nick.fogleman
articles.summary: FEMA hosted an Agricultural Recovery Center in Watauga County on Jan. 31 to provide the agriculture industry aid in their recovery from Hurricane Helene. Several federal, state, and local agencies and non-profits met with agricultural producers to assist them with the many programs that have been assisting in the area.

articles.title: The Western Monarch Butterfly Population Has Plummeted This Winter
articles.author: Bianca Barr
articles.summary: The number of monarch butterflies in California is in decline this year. The Western Monarch Count has reported a peak population of 9,119 this winter, down from approximately 200,000 overwintering butterflies counted each year over the past three years. This is the second-lowest population recording since tracking began in 1997. Monarchs are being proposed for protection under the U.S. Endangered Species Act.

articles.title: Changing data to agree with the narrative? The sad story of ACORN-SAT
articles.author: Eric Worrall
articles.summary: Bill Johnston has been researching Australian weather station datasets for almost two decades. He is sceptical about the quality of the data they rely on to monitor Australia's climate. The main problem for ACORN-SAT and its precursor high-quality datasets is that weather stations were not set-up to measure trend and change, but to monitor local weather.

articles.title: Heat related deaths in Spain could surge by hundreds of thousands due to climate change, experts warn - Olive Press News Spain
articles.author: Yzabelle Bostyn
articles.summary: Warming could cause over 2.3 million extra deaths in Europe by the end of this century. Barcelona is the city with the largest increase in heat-related deaths by 2099, followed by Rome, Rome, Naples, Naples and Madrid. Valencia is also in the top ten cities with the greatest expected increase in deaths.

articles.title: Get ready for the Great Backyard Bird Count
articles.author: Charles Seabrook
articles.summary: A new assessment from the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service shows that 96 million Americans engage in bird-watching. In Georgia, at least 15% of the state's 11 million residents are bird-watchers. This month, bird lovers worldwide have a chance to show their affection for the creatures by participating in the 2025 Great Backyard Bird Count.

articles.title: At the forefront: Farmers share their experiences of a changing climate in Ireland
articles.author: Stephen Cadogan
articles.summary: Farmers have been telling their weather stories for a report commissioned by the Climate Change Advisory Council. Unpredictable weather, rising costs, and the uncertainty of the future is a constant struggle for a beef and sheep farmer. A dairy farmer's investment in an automatic milking system with automated gates was not driven by the need to adapt to climate. Organic farming is a potential climate adaptation measure.

articles.title: Climate change target of 2C is ‘dead', says renowned climate scientist
articles.author: Damian Carrington
articles.summary: Prof James Hansen and his team say the international 2C target is 'dead' because global energy use is rising and it will continue to rise. Global heating is likely to reach 2C by 2045 unless solar geoengineering is deployed. The world's nations pledged in Paris in 2015 to keep global temperature rise below 2C.

articles.title: Op ed: DEP's land use rules, as proposed, will stand in the way of Gov. Murphy's affordable housing goals
articles.author: temp3
articles.summary: The Department of Environmental Protection is likely finalizing its Land Use rules proposed last summer. Many municipal and county officials in areas with tidal waters are opposed to the provisions that will make New Jersey less affordable and equitable. Gov. Phil Murphy made a strong push for the reform of local zoning and planning rules to fulfill the mission of a broad affordable housing law he signed last year.

articles.title: Green Bay saw an unusual combination of weather in January
articles.summary: January was 19.5 degrees warmer than average in Green Bay. The warmest January on record was in 2006. It was also the least snowy January since 2006. January saw only 15 hundredths of an inch of precipitation, which is the 2nd driest on record. January 2006 saw above-average precipitation due to several rainy days.

articles.title: Glazebrook Park sees crowds on unseasonably warm February day
articles.author: John Badman
articles.summary: It was 71 degrees at 3:50 p.m. on Monday, February 3, 2025. The temperature topped out at 71.6 degrees. It was just a few degrees shy of the 75-degree record for the date, set in 1890. Dozens of people were out walking in the 70-degree weather.

articles.title: Warming threatens to expand area of world too hot for humans
articles.author: ETX Studio
articles.summary: Warming threatens to expand area of world too hot for humans. Extreme heat will reach dangerous levels across an area equivalent to the size of the United States if Earth's global warming hits two degrees Celsius. Last year, more than 1,300 people died at the hajj pilgrimage in Saudi Arabia where temperatures hit 51.8C.

articles.title: Lethal heat waves will triple in size even if climate agreements kept, study finds
articles.author: Saul Elbein
articles.summary: There is an urgent need for hot-weather countries to adapt to prepare for 'unsurvivable heat thresholds', according to the study published in Nature Reviews Earth and Environment. Under current levels of warming, such heat events currently afflict about 2 percent of the Earth's landmass, or about 14 times the size of Texas. For adults over 60, the risk is ten times higher. If average temperatures rise to 2 degrees Celsius (3.6 degrees Fahrenheit) above pre-industrial levels, then the regions affected by lethal heat waves will spread.

articles.title: Attorney Mike McIntyre Honored with NCBIWA's Hero of the Coast Award
articles.author: Robesonian
articles.summary: Mike McIntyre received the Hero of the Coast Award from North Carolina Beach, Inlet, and Waterway Association. McIntyre is a former U.S. Congressman and now Senior Advisor for Government Relations and Economic Development at Ward and Smith. He served the Seventh Congressional District from 1997 to 2015.

articles.title: Arctic sea ice levels second lowest on record for January: US data
articles.author: Paris  –
articles.summary: The US National Snow and Ice Data Center said the Arctic sea ice surface area was at a record low in December and continued near record lows in January. In contrast to the cold conditions dominating the contiguous United States, much of the Arctic experienced above-average January temperatures. This was particularly marked north of Greenland and over central Alaska.

articles.title: Arctic sea ice levels second lowest on record for January: US data
articles.author: AFP
articles.summary: The sea ice in the Arctic was the second lowest on record for January last month. Both the North and South Pole regions have warmed by some three degrees Celsius compared to late 19th-century levels, much faster than the global average. Areas around Greenland are seeing well above average temperatures.

articles.title: Global cities at risk of growing rat infestations fueled by climate change and rise in temperatures
articles.author: London Evening Standard
articles.summary: Warming temperatures from the burning of coal, oil and natural gas is contributing to the surge in rat populations, according to the researchers. The rise in rat numbers is due to the warming of the climate.      Â   i

articles.title: 10 Shocking Comparisons: Life Before and After Climate Change
articles.author: John Dyson
articles.summary: In the not-so-distant past, the world's climate showed a comforting predictability. Today, record-breaking heatwaves are a regular headline across the globe. The Arctic is warming up at a pace four times faster than the world average. The world was once a vibrant tapestry of life, dotted by lush rainforests and dazzling coral reefs, but now the vibrancy is dimming. Deforestation accelerates carbon emissions and wipes out countless habitats.

articles.title: Half a degree rise in global warming will triple area of Earth that is 'too hot for humans'
articles.author: Julia Musto
articles.summary: Just half a degree rise of global warming will triple the size of the area of Earth that is considered to be too hot for humans. The affected area consists of different parts of the planet's landmass and includes Africa, the Middle East, and South Asia. For adults over the age of 60, the threat of heatstroke expands. Saharan Africa and south Asia are at the highest risk.

articles.title: World Bank says Zimbabwe's US$12.5 billion agricultural target under threat
articles.author: Nyashadzashe Ndoro
articles.summary: Zimbabwe's goal to boost agricultural output to US$12.5 billion is facing significant threats due to climate-induced challenges. The 2023/24 El Niño-induced drought caused approximately US$363 million in damage losses, resulting in a projected 3.2% drop in GDP. The World Bank recommends a dual approach involving investment in climate adaptation and the enhancement of anticipatory actions.

articles.title: Temperatures at north pole 20C above average and beyond ice melting point
articles.author: Ajit Niranjan
articles.summary: Temperatures at the north pole soared more than 20C above average on Sunday, crossing the threshold for ice to melt. The Arctic has warmed nearly four times faster than the global average since 1979, and extreme heat has become hotter and more common. A study coauthored in 2023 found Arctic summer sea ice will be lost even with drastic cuts to planet-heating pollution.

articles.title: Grande Prairie is the coldest place in the world!
articles.author: Erika Rolling
articles.summary: Grande Prairie is the coldest place on Earth at -39 degrees Celsius. Chetwynd B.C., Cold Lake, High Level, and Slave Lake are the other coldest places in the world today. Extreme cold temperatures are expected to hold going into Wednesday. Most of Alberta and the BC Peace will warm up into the mid-negative-teen's for the foreseeable future.

articles.title: NiMET predicts heavy rainfall in May, June
articles.author: Matthew Atungwu
articles.summary: The Nigerian Meteorological Agency, NiMet, has predicted high-intensity rainfall between May and June 2025 in coastal cities of the country. The Minister of Aviation and Aerospace Development, Festus Keyamo, presented the annual climate prediction for the year 2025 in Abuja. The onset of rain is predicted to be delayed over the northern and central states of Plateau, Kaduna, Niger, Benue, Nasarawa, Taraba, Adamawa, and Kwara. The end-of-rainy season is predicted earlier than long-term average over parts of Zamfara, Katsina, Kano and Kaduna.

articles.title: Calls to dial up heatwave response as temperatures soar
articles.author: Poppy Johnston
articles.summary: "Heat is going to become more of a problem to our communities as we go forward, and therefore our governments need to anticipate that and act to keep us safe," says Mr. Rennie. "The government needs to anticipate this and act on it."

articles.title: Ecology Clubs in schools to raise climate awareness: CM
articles.author: NT Bureau
articles.summary: Tamil Nadu Chief Minister MK Stalin announced the establishment of ecology clubs in all schools across the state to educate students and the public on climate change. He also revealed that Tamil Nadu would soon unveil a dedicated climate change policy. Tamil Nadu remains the only state to organize exclusive climate summits.

articles.title: UWI Researchers at the Forefront of Pioneering Health and Climate Change Study for Small Island Developing States
articles.summary: The University of the West Indies (The UWI) is pleased to announce that 13 of its experts are co-authors of a groundbreaking inaugural study that highlights the increasing health risks posed by climate change to Small Island Developing States (SIDS). Dr Georgiana Gordon-Strachan is the lead author of the report. The report will be launched during a live online event on February 6, 2025 at 4:30 PM EST/Jamaica Time. The involvement of The UWI academics highlights the University's commitment to the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs).

articles.title: ‘Over 25.6% of Odisha's shoreline saw erosion between 1990 & 2018'
articles.summary: Kendrapada, Odisha's shoreline, spanning 140.72km, witnessed erosion between 1990 and 2018. 51% of the coast, extending 280.02km, saw accretion, while 23.4% remained stable out of the total 549.5 km-long coastline. 33.6% of India's coastline faces erosion, while 26.8% experiences accretion and 39% maintains stability.

articles.title: How will climate change affect real estate markets in Wisconsin? Here's what one study found
articles.author: Alex Groth
articles.summary: Real estate values in the U.S. could decline by over $1 trillion by 2055 due to climate change. Some areas will see a 1.7% decline in property values over the next 30 years. Tampa, Florida, could see as much as 25%. Wisconsin is one of the least vulnerable states in the nation against climate risks.

articles.title: How will climate change affect real estate markets in Wisconsin? Here's what one study found
articles.author: Alex Groth
articles.summary: Real estate values in the U.S. could decline by over $1 trillion by 2055 due to climate change. Some areas will see a 1.7% decline in property values over the next 30 years. Tampa, Florida, could see a 25% decline. Wisconsin is one of the least vulnerable states in the nation against climate risks.

articles.title: Experts warn Brock Township of rising health risks from climate change
articles.author: Darryl Knight
articles.summary: Durham Region's Health Protection Division recently presented a detailed report to Brock Township Council. The presentation focused on extreme heat and other vulnerabilities identified in a series of reports mandated by the Ontario Public Health Standards. The first report was released in August 2024 and serves as a primer for understanding the broader health implications of a changing climate. Subsequent reports address specific vulnerabilities.

articles.title: Reality getting in the way of aspirations
articles.summary: Dunedin's plan to be a zero-emitter of carbon emissions by 2030 was one of the great initiatives of the Dunedin City Council. The council is on track to make its zero-carbon commitments. The report to councillors last week delivered the bad news that the city, as a whole, was unlikely to make it. The change of government in October 2023 had started a chain reaction which would make the target less achievable.

articles.title: Greenland Ice Sheet is cracking quicker than scientists thought
articles.summary: Greenland Ice Sheet, the world's second biggest body of ice, is cracking open quicker than scientists had previously thought. Cracks in the ice have increased in size and depth near the edges of the ice sheet between 2016 and 2021. If the whole Greenland Ice Sheet was to melt, sea levels could rise by seven metres.

articles.title: Tamil Nadu CM Stalin to introduce climate change policy for educational purposes
articles.author: ANI
articles.summary: Tamil Nadu Chief Minister MK Stalin announced on Tuesday that his government will introduce a climate change policy exclusively for educational purposes. He was speaking at the Tamil Nadu Climate Summit 3.0 organised here. In all schools across Tamil Nadu, ecology clubs will be established. Training will be provided to staff in various government departments to help them address climate change.

articles.title: Drought continues to weight on Morocco's job market
articles.author: North Africa Post
articles.summary: The number of unemployed in Morocco reached 1.638 million people last year. The unemployment rate was notably worst among the youth at 36.7% and women at 19.4%. Climate volatility causes job losses in the farming sector, propelling a migration to low-added value service jobs such as retail and handicrafts.

articles.title: Half a degree rise in global warming will triple area of Earth too hot for humans, scientists warn
articles.author: Science X staff
articles.summary: The amount of landmass that would be too hot for even healthy young humans to keep a safe core body temperature will triple if global warming reaches 2°C above the preindustrial average. The area of land where the over 60s will be at risk will increase to about 35%. Saharan Africa and South Asia are most at risk.

articles.title: IMPACT OF GLOBAL WARMING AND CLIMATE CHANGE ON FARMERS (Ministry of Agriculture & Farmers Welfare of the Republic of India)
articles.author: Public Technologies
articles.summary: The Government has taken several steps towards mitigation of the adverse impact of global warming and climate change on farmers. PIB Delhi has received the report from the Ministry of Agriculture & Farmers Welfare.    It will be presented on 4th February 2025 at 7:04 PM.

articles.title: California Economy Braces for Housing Turmoil as Experts Warn Alarming Future is Near
articles.author: The Politicians
articles.summary: A study by First Street Foundation predicts changes in the climate could wipe out $1.47 trillion in US home values by 2055. California, Florida and Texas are expected to bear the brunt of this loss. The Central Valley, particularly areas prone to wildfires, is expected to see significant home value declines. The study predicts climate change and rising insurance costs will prompt 55 million Americans to relocate to less climate-vulnerable regions by 20 55.

articles.title: The 6th great mass extinction: How to protect biodiversity in Wisconsin
articles.author: Isiah Holmes
articles.summary: There has been a 73% decline in the population sizes of over 5,400 vertebrate (backboned) species since 1970. About 3 billion birds have been lost in the United States and Canada over a single human lifetime. 40% of insect species worldwide were declining, and expected to disappear entirely within a century. Wisconsin has eight bat species that haven't been in the state since 1950. The northern blue butterfly has been extirpated from Wisconsin.

articles.title: Mosca: la ricerca di cibo tra le neve di un uccellino
articles.author: Temi caldi
articles.summary: Moscow region is experiencing spring weather in January and February 2025, with temperatures five degrees Celsius above the climatic norm. A bird searches for food at a park during a warm weather day outside Moscow, Russia, on 04 February 2025. EPA/MAXIM SHIPENKOV.

articles.title: NiMet predicts delayed rainfall in Northern states
articles.author: Latestnigeriannews
articles.summary: Nigeria Meteorological Agency has released the 2025 Seasonal Climate Prediction (SCP) with a forecast of delayed rainfall over the northern and central states of Plateau, Kaduna, Niger, Benue, Nasarawa, Taraba, Adamawa, and Kwara. The forecast projected early onset over the southern states of Delta, Bayelsa, Rivers, Anambra and Delta.

articles.title: Romina for climate prosperity through bold economic resilience strategies
articles.author: JAVAID UR RAHMAN
articles.summary: Ms Romina Khurshid Alam is Coordinator to the Prime Minister for Climate Change. She met with a high-level delegation of the Climate Vulnerable Forum (CVF) of the Vulnerable Twenty (V20) Group. CVF is a key international coalition of 70 countries representing 1.75 billion people across Africa, Asia, the Caribbean, Latin America and the Pacific.

articles.title: Russia Controls Melting Arctic
articles.author: Douglas McIntyre
articles.summary: The northern part of Greenland borders the Arctic coastline. The Russian proximity advantage has strategic military value. Much of the ice has melted due to global warming. Commercial ships can save hundreds of miles in transit when navigating through the Arctic Circle. The number of voyages through the Northern Sea Route has climbed steadily, from fewer than 20 in 2015 to almost 100 in 2024.

articles.title: Tamil Nadu to establish ecology clubs in schools to create awareness on climate change
articles.author: ETB Sivapriyan
articles.summary: Stalin emphasised the need for a climate change policy at the state level to respond adequately to disasters whose intensity and frequency have increased in the past decade and to prepare for future climate change events.      .   in his speech.

articles.title: Kashmir witnesses 75% dip in precipitation in January
articles.summary: Kashmir is losing its sheen due to changes in weather patterns across the region. In January 2025, Kashmir Valley witnessed a 75 per cent dip in precipitation and day temperatures have risen 6 degrees above the normal. Watch the video to find out more details.

articles.title: UNICEF USA BrandVoice: How To Turn Climate Hardship Into Hope In Eastern And Southern Africa
articles.author: Maryanne Murray Buechner
articles.summary: At least 51 million children in Eastern and Southern Africa are at the epicenter of the climate crisis. Since 1980, El Niño has made its presence felt eight times, with the latest surge beginning in June 2023. El Niño occurs when the trade winds are weaker and La Niña occurs when they are stronger. Both are intensified by global warming.

articles.title: UAH v6.1 Global Temperature Update for January, 2025: +0.46 deg. C
articles.author: Guest Blogger

articles.title: The Greenland ice sheet is falling apart

articles.summary: Australia has grown its population by around 8.5 million this century. Most of the migration is purportedly skilled. However, Australia's skills shortages are worse than ever despite the surge in' skilled' migration, according to Greg Jericho from The Guardian.   .

articles.title: Queensland Floods, Victoria Fires and Storms Hit Hard
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: The Climate Council says climate pollution is amplifying the extreme rain and flooding that's pummelled Queenslanders. Victorians have also been shaken by extreme conditions this week. Professor David Karoly is a climate scientist. He believes the solution is to switch to renewable energy, battery storage, cleaner transport and manufacturing.

articles.title: UK scientists plan to monitor krill from space as species threatened by warming
articles.author: AOL
articles.summary: Humpback whales migrate thousands of miles every year to feed in the icy waters around Antarctica. They are climate heroes too, playing a critical role in drawing down carbon from the ocean surface, according to the scientists. But climate change is still a problem.

articles.title: Climate justice for Zim: Who pays for the damage?
articles.author: William Duri
articles.summary: Rising temperatures, changing rainfall patterns, and increased frequency of extreme weather events are threatening the livelihoods of many in Zimbabwe. Climate change disproportionately affects low-income households, indigenous peoples, and small-island developing states. The Government is taking steps to promote climate justice in Zimbabwe, including the development of Zimbabwe's Nationally Determined Contribution.

articles.title: Australia's UV levels are high, but the ozone hole isn't the culprit
articles.author: system
articles.summary: The Australian summer sun feels harsher than a summer in the Northern Hemisphere, so why that's the case may surprise you. It's because of the heat in the summer in Australia, which is warmer than in the northern hemisphere. It can be very hot in Australia.

articles.title: Hillsborough produces a lot of trash. Its landfill is filling up.
articles.author: Tampa Bay Times
articles.summary: Hurricanes Helene and Milton have helped speed up the expansion of the landfill in Hillsborough County. The area is quickly filling with new homes and garbage is being produced and collected faster than previously projected, which is increasing the amount of waste collected.

articles.title: Climate change threatens Karnataka's environmental future: forest minister
articles.author: India Today
articles.summary: Climate change threatens Karnatakas environmental future forest minister, he says. He is concerned about the impact of climate change on the environment and environment policy in general. He's also worried about the future of the forest in Karnatsakas.

articles.title: Climate change target of 2C is ‘dead', says renowned climate scientist
articles.author: AOL
articles.summary: The pace of global warming has been underestimated, according to Prof James Hansen. The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPPC) defined a scenario which gives a 50% chance to keep warming under 2C, but that scenario is now impossible, says Hansen.

articles.title: Greenland's ice sheet is fracturing faster than ever; what it means for rising sea levels
articles.author: The Times
articles.summary: The Greenland ice sheet is cracking open more faster than before due to climate change. The study was conducted by researchers from Durham University, UK. It analyzed over 8,000 3D images of the Greenland Ice Sheet and found that climate change is to blame for the problem.

articles.title: Deaths of 30,000 fish off WA coast made more likely by climate change, research finds
articles.author: The Guardian
articles.summary: Analysis draws on satellite data and 13 climate models to conclude that climate change makes marine heatwaves 20 times more likely.    For confidential support call the Samaritans on 08457 90 90 90 or visit a local Samaritans branch, or click here for details.

articles.title: Half a degree rise in global warming will triple area of Earth too hot for humans (King's College London)
articles.author: Public Technologies
articles.summary: Global warming will lead to more parts of the planet becoming too hot for the human body over the coming decades, according to a paper published in Nature Reviews Earth and Environment. The amount of landmass on the planet is increasing.       i

articles.title: Athlete ready to risk Arctic frostbite in 'hardest, most epic' race yet
articles.author: system
articles.summary: Adelaide's Aaron Crook is the sole Australian among 11 global competitors. They will race each other 620 kilometres in temperatures as low as -50 degrees Celsius across the Arctic Circle. The competition starts on Sunday.      .   i

articles.title: Compost as counter to global warming
articles.author: Deccan Herald
articles.summary: In 2015, 195 nations signed the Paris Agreement and pledged to limit the temperature increase to 1.5°C above pre-industrial levels. In 2024, the global average temperature was 1.60°C warmer than the previous year. With Trump as President, the United States has withdrawn from the agreement.

articles.title: Warming threatens to expand area of world too hot for humans
articles.author: News24
articles.summary: Extreme heat will reach dangerous levels across an area equivalent to the size of the US if Earth's global warming hits two degrees Celsius, scientists warn.      .   "Even for younger people, even for young people, it will be dangerous"

articles.title: A third of Arabian Gulf marine life could be extinct by 2090, researchers warn
articles.author: The National
articles.summary: A third of the Arabian Gulf's marine species could be wiped out by 2090 due to rising sea temperatures. Oceans are heating up faster than previously predicted, and the shallow basin of the Gulf is already warming up fast.    i.e. the sea surface is getting warmer.

articles.title: Revealed: The 10 worst methane emitting regions on EARTH that churn out millions of tonnes ...
articles.author: The Daily Mail
articles.summary: Methane is 28 times more potent than CO2 at trapping heat in the atmosphere. It is the primary component of natural gas and is responsible for about a third of the global warming potential of the natural gas.   .

articles.title: Lethal heat waves will triple in size even if climate agreements kept, study finds
articles.author: The Hill
articles.summary: Heat waves that are impossible to survive without air-conditioning could afflict far more of the globe than they do now, according to a new study published in Nature. This could happen even if climate change is kept within the limits of international agreements. Longer outdoor exposure would be expected to cause lethal heatstroke.

articles.title: How African farmers are adapting to mountain climate change
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: new international study highlights the severity of climate change impacts. It is based on data from the UNFCCC. It's based on the IPCC's own data. It also includes data from other international studies. It shows that climate change is a serious problem.

articles.title: Hurricane Helene's $5 billion toll strains NCDOT resources, Transportation Secretary Joey Hopkins says
articles.author: Business Journal
articles.summary: Hurricane Helene's $5 billion price tag forces North Carolina to navigate uncharted waters in infrastructure recovery. North Carolina is trying to recover from Hurricane Helene at a cost of $5.5 billion. The recovery is expected to take place over the next few years.

articles.title: Antarctica: The last untouched continent
articles.author: Virtual Jerusalem
articles.summary: There are more than 500 billion reasons why Antarctica could be under threat, according to Al Jazeera's research. Read more Al Jazeera Breaking News, World News and Video from Al Jazeera here.   .   for more news and video on Al Jazeera.

articles.title: Could manmade aerosols prevent global warming?
articles.author: Virtual Jerusalem
articles.summary: El Niño may have subsided, but the temperature is not going down. It's just stabilizing, which is very alarming, according to the scientist who wrote the article.    "The temperature isn't going down, but it's stabilizing and that's alarming"

articles.title: Report reveals 9.6-bln-USD annual cost of saving Australian species from extinction
articles.author: Xinhua
articles.summary: Saving Australia's priority species from extinction would cost almost 10 billion U.S. dollars annually for 30 years. Preventing extinction for 99 priority species would cost an estimated 15.6 billion Australian dollars (9.6 billions dollars) Report published on Tuesday.

articles.title: Climate change is overhauling marine nutrient cycles, scientists say
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: Computer models reveal how human-driven climate change will dramatically overhaul critical nutrient cycles in the ocean, as predicted by climate change models. In the article "In the Ocean: How Climate Change Will Alter Critical Nutrient Cycles in the Ocean" by Andrew Hammond, he explains how this could happen.

articles.title: Antisemitism Rises to Shocking Levels in Australia — But the Media Doesn't Care
articles.author: The Algemeiner
articles.summary: Arsonists damaged the Adass Israel Synagogue in Melbourne, Australia, on Dec. 6, 2024. The Jews are the proverbial "canary in the coal mine" because of Hamas' October 7, 2023, terror attacks on Israel.

articles.title: Study examines how African farmers are adapting to mountain climate change
articles.author: Science Daily
articles.summary: A new international study highlights the severity of climate change impacts across African mountains and how farmers are adapting. The findings are relevant to people living in mountain regions around the world.      .   "Climate change impacts on African mountains: How farmers adapt and what barriers they face"

articles.author: Public Technologies

articles.title: Climate adaptation in the telecommunications sector – ISPA ARP4 report (ISPA - Internet Services Providers' Association)
articles.author: Public Technologies
articles.summary: The effects of climate change are recognised as a key threat to critical national infrastructure by the UK Government. Every five years the Department for the Environment, Food and Rural Affairs (Defra) updates its assessment of the threat to national infrastructure. It is based on the assessment made every five years by Defra.

articles.title: THE SOLUTION TO THE SEA INVADING THE COAST AND FOR GLOBAL WARMING
articles.author: The Petition Site
articles.summary: The cause and solution for the sea invading the coastal region are the same that have generated global warming and many other pernicious climate changes. I am teaching and proving all of this in my book RESTORING CLIMATIC NORMALITY, a sample of which can be accessed at

articles.title: Letter: President Trump's policies will contribute to global warming
articles.author: Polk County Itemiser-Observer
articles.summary: This is just a reminder that global warming is real. Earth is warming at an increasing rate, sea level is rising, and severe weather events are occurring at increasing rate. Policies advocated by President Trump are to blame for global warming. The president's policies to combat it are to focus on energy production.

articles.title: Greenland's ice sheet cracks more swiftly due to climate change
articles.author: MENA FN
articles.summary: Greenland's ice sheet is breaking apart due to climate change, according to a recent study published on Monday. The research was conducted by Durham University in the UK and led by Michael Højkjaer from the University of Manchester.

articles.title: The Greenland ice sheet is falling apart: New study
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: The main problem with observing Greenland from a helicopter is comprehending the scale. It's like skimming low over the waves of a fjord instead of skimming over the sea. It can be difficult to see the difference between a helicopter and a plane.

articles.title: Dry Conditions Prompt Fire Restrictions In Otago's Alpine Area
articles.author: Scoop
articles.summary: Otago District Manager Phil Marsh says the current warm, dry weather is forecast to continue over the next few weeks, raising the fire risk in Otago's fragile alpine environment. The current warm weather is expected to continue for a few more weeks.

articles.title: Indonesia mulls Paris Agreement exit, citing fairness and energy transition costs
articles.author: Mongabay
articles.summary: Indonesia is one of the world's largest greenhouse gas emitters. It might follow the U.S. and withdraw from the Paris climate agreement. Indonesia is the second-biggest greenhouse gas emitter after China. It is not clear why it should comply with the international agreement.

articles.title: The Greenland ice sheet is falling apart
articles.author: The Conversation
articles.summary: Tom Chudley is observing Greenland from a helicopter. He has seen icebergs the size of office floating on the sea floor below. He is trying to comprehend the scale of the icebergs he is observing from the helicopter, but it's difficult to do so.

articles.title: Embrace climate risk insurance
articles.author: Zainab Naeem
articles.summary: Climate risk insurance is a crucial lifeline for communities facing the devastating impacts of a rapidly changing climate. According to the International Finance Corporation, the demand for climate risk insurance in developing countries is projected to grow exponentially, with the market potential estimated at $200 billion by 2030. Microfinance institutions (MFIs) are emerging as key players in bridging the gap between vulnerable populations and climate-related insurance. MFIs are uniquely positioned to democratise access to climate insurance.

articles.title: Andrew S. Lewis
articles.author: Andrew S. Lewis
articles.summary: Climate change is driving shifts in the abundance and distribution of species in the sea. Some fish predators and prey, like striped bass and menhaden on the U.S. East Coast, are changing their behavior as the waters warm. Scientists are just beginning to focus on why.

articles.title: Letter: Messages surrounding UK climate change are causing confusion
articles.author: Letters
articles.summary: Last month the UK suffered the coldest night for 15 years, when temperatures fell to -18.7C. Yet the so-called 'climate experts' tell us we're all going to die shortly due to the unbearable heat affecting the planet. Have I got it right?

articles.title: Climate arrogance
articles.summary: Don Chioffi wrote a column in The Times Argus/Rutland Herald a couple weeks ago in which he posited the theory that 9.3 billion people have little or nothing to do with climate change. He also intimated that scientists who subscribe to the theory human activity is the cause of global warming are peddling pseudo-science.

articles.title: Top climate scientist declares 2C climate goal 'dead'
articles.author: ANDY BUCHANAN
articles.summary: Holding long-term global warming to two degrees Celsius is now impossible, according to a new analysis published by leading scientists. Earth's climate is more sensitive to rising greenhouse gas emissions than previously thought, says the paper.    Javascript is required for you to be able to read premium content.

articles.title: Climate arrogance
articles.summary: Don Chioffi wrote a column in The Times Argus/Rutland Herald, in which he posited the theory that 9.3 billion people have little or nothing to do with climate change. Strat Douthat disagrees with him, because he sounds arrogant and pseudo-scientific.

articles.title: Great Backyard Bird Count is scheduled for Feb. 14-17
articles.author: Staff Reports
articles.summary: This year is the 28th annual Great Backyard Bird Count taking place on February 14-17, 2025. More than a half-million people participated in the 2024 count. They reported 7,920 species of birds from 200-plus countries and subregions.

articles.title: Greenland's parliament approves a ban on foreign political donations as Trump seeks the island
articles.summary: NASA scientists are on a mission to track melting ice in eastern Greenland. They are flying on a plane with icebergs on the window. They will land on February 4, 2025 at 5:24 pm.      Â  .
